questions.answer_ET: D. By adding all subnets listed by the show ip route static command
questions.answer: D. By adding all subnets listed by the show ip route static command
questions.question_text: Which of the following are methods EIGRP uses to initially populate (seed) its EIGRP topology table, before learning topology data from neighbors? (Choose two.)
questions.answer_description: Other than the two listed correct answers, the local router also adds connected routes for which the network command matches the corresponding interfaces, so it may not add all connected routes. Also, EIGRP does not add static routes to the EIGRP topology table, unless those routes are redistributed.

discussion.content:
B. By adding the subnets of working interfaces over which static neighbors have been defined
C. By adding subnets redistributed on the local router from another routing source

choices.C: By adding subnets redistributed on the local router from another routing source
choices.B: By adding the subnets of working interfaces over which static neighbors have been defined
choices.A: By adding all subnets listed by the show ip route connected command

questions.question_text: How is authentication handled with OSPFv3?

discussion.content: A. OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by IPv6 IPsec.

choices.C: OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by IPv4 IPsec.
choices.B: OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by MD5 authentication.
choices.A: OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by IPv6 IPsec.

questions.answer: D. OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by SHA-1 authentication.
questions.answer_ET: D. OSPFv3 for IPv6 authentication is supported by SHA-1 authentication.

choices.C: The redistribution command should be reentered with the metric metric-value parameter included.
choices.B: The redistribution command should be reentered with the route-map map-tag parameter included.
choices.A: The redistribution command should be reentered with the match route-type parameter included.

questions.answer_ET: D. Routes will first need to be distributed into another protocol, and then into RIP.
questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
Notice that RIP metric is based on hop count only, and the maximum valid metric is 15. Anything above 15 is considered infinite. By default, when no metric is assigned when redistributing from EIGRP, OSPF, IS-IS, BGP into RIP, the default metric will be infinite. Therefore we must define a metric that is understandable to the receiving protocol. Usually, we should use a small value (like 1, 2, 3) so that after redistributing, that route can be advertised through many routers (because the limit is 15).
questions.answer: D. Routes will first need to be distributed into another protocol, and then into RIP.

discussion.content: C. The redistribution command should be reentered with the metric metric-value parameter included.

questions.answer: E. OSPF routes can be exported into BGP.
questions.question_text: Which two statements about route redistribution when implementing OSPF are true? (Choose two.)
questions.answer_ET: E. OSPF routes can be exported into BGP.

discussion.content:
Missing:
E. OSPF routes can be exported into BGP.

Correct answer:
B, E

choices.A: Routes learned using any IP routing protocol can only be redistributed into non IP routing protocols.
choices.C: OSPF routes cannot be exported into EIGRP, RIP, and IS-IS.
choices.D: At the interdomain level, OSPF cannot import routes learned using BGP.
choices.B: OSPF can import routes learned using EIGRP, RIP, and IS-IS.

questions.question_text: Which two routing interface parameters are supported in OSPF implementations? (Choose two.)
questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
When OSPF sends an advertisement to an adjacent router, it expects to receive an acknowledgment from that neighbor. If no acknowledgment is received, the router will retransmit the advertisement to its neighbor. The retransmit-interval timer controls the number of seconds between retransmissions. To edit the retransmit-interval, use the ip ospf retransmit-interval seconds in interface configuration mode.
Dead-interval is the number of seconds without hello packets before an adjacency is declared down. To edit the dead-interval, use the ip ospf dead-interval seconds in interface configuration mode.
Other answers are not correct because they are not interface parameters.
